column2: The following is an attempt to create a computer friendly featural alphabet that can be used in place of the IPA
It is not intended to be easily read or written outside programming.
It is only meant to express broad sound laws that reoccur across many languages
without having to consider all the possible characters that are supported by the IPA.
Vowel modifiers ↑ and → can be repeated, the number of repetitions indicates cartesian coordinates on the vowel chart
A base character indicates the origin of the cartesian coordinate system.
For instance, 'u' could be denoted either 'ɯʷ' or 'ə↑→ʷ' or 'a↑↑↑→→ʷ'. 'a' could be denoted 'a' or 'ə↓←'.
It is up to the user to select a base character that is best suited for the sound law.
For instance a sound law that represents a rotation within vowel space may use a pivot such as 'ə' as the origin to simplify logic,
whereas a simple heightening or fronting may be easiest to implement using 'a'.
Characters for fricatives are used to denote place of articulation since IPA symbols exist for all possible placements
plosives are denoted by ᵖ, voiced consonants by ᵛ
